subject: Re: PrivilegedAccessor Object Array Cannot Contain "null" Value?
msgSnippet: Hi J.B., Because I want to test what happens if I pass in a null into my method.  My method does certain business logic and I want to test that it handles null
messageBody:
Hi J.B.,
Because I want to test what happens if I pass in a null into my
method. My method does certain business logic and I want to test
that it handles null properly. So, in reality if the method's not
private, I would be able to call this:

String abc = "hello";
myMethod(null,abc);

so I want to see whether of myMethod throws the correct exception.

When using PrivilegedAccessor.invokeMethod, then, I need to pass the
two parameters of null and abc as an Object array for its third
argument. Does that make sense?

Thanks,
Kris.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
>
> krispyjala wrote:
> > Hello,
> > I'm running into this problem where the PrivilegedAccessor
cannot
> > find the method when using invokeMethod() if the Object array
> > contains a null value.
> >
> > Ex:
> >
> > PrivilegedAccessor.invokeMethod(Class.class,"myMethod",new Object
[]
> > {null,arg1});
> >
> > I think the problem lies in the fact that underneath,
invokeMethod's
> > calling getMethod which calls another getMethod, which ultimately
> > calls java.lang.getDeclaredMethod() which only accepts an array of
> > classes. Since null is not a class, it throws an exception and
thus
> > the private method is declared not found. Am I right? Or am I
> > missing something?
> >
> > When I replaced the null with a valid object, it was able to find
the
> > private method fine. Is this a bug, or is this something that I
> > shouldn't be doing (setting null as an element in the Object
array?).
>
> In general, arrays can hold null values; but in this particular
case,
> what is the null meant to signify? Why are you trying to pass null?
